===== Bhitarkanika mangroves ===== The [[Bhitarkanika]] mangroves form India’s second largest forest, located in the state of Odisha. Bhitarkanika is created by the two river deltas of Brahmani and Baitarani river and one of the important Ramsar Wetland in India. It is also the home of [[saltwater crocodile]]s and nesting [[olive ridley]] sea turtles.<ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_wetland"/><ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_forest">{{cite web|url=http://www.walkthroughindia.com/walkthroughs/top-5-largest-mangrove-and-swamp-forest-in-india/|title=Top 5 Largest Mangrove And Swamp Forest in India|publisher=}}</ref>
===== Godavari-Krishna mangroves ===== The Godavari-Krishna mangroves lie in the delta of the [[Godavari]] and [[Krishna River|Krishna]] rivers in the state of [[Andhra Pradesh]]. Mangroves ecoregion is under protection for [[Calimere]] Wildlife and [[Pulicat Lake Bird Sanctuary]].<ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_forest"/>
===== Pichavaram mangroves ===== [[File:Pichavaram 1.jpg|thumb|Pichavaram hosts the second largest mangrove forests in the world]] The [[Pichavaram]] mangroves are situated at Pichavaram near [[Chidambaram]] in the state of [[Tamil Nadu]]. Pichavaram ranks amongst one of the most exquisite scenic spots in Tamil Nadu and has many species of aquatic birds.<ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_forest"/>
===== Mumbai mangroves ===== The [[megacity]] [[Mumbai]] has mangroves on its coastline along the west coast of India. A total of 10 mangrove species were reported in this area, domiated by ''Avicennia marina''.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.rsma.2018.02.011 |title=Vegetative structure and species composition of mangroves along the Mumbai coast, Maharashtra, India |journal=Regional Studies in Marine Science |volume=19 |pages=1 |year=2018 |last1=Kantharajan |first1=G |last2=Pandey |first2=P.K |last3=Krishnan |first3=P |last4=Ragavan |first4=P |last5=Jeevamani |first5=J. Joyson Joe |last6=Purvaja |first6=R |last7=Ramesh |first7=R }}</ref> These mangroves support a rich diversity of life forms, especially molluscs.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.rsma.2017.06.002 |title=Molluscan diversity in the mangrove ecosystem of Mumbai, west coast of India |journal=Regional Studies in Marine Science |volume=14 |pages=102–11 |year=2017 |last1=Kantharajan |first1=G |last2=Pandey |first2=P.K |last3=Krishnan |first3=P |last4=Deepak Samuel |first4=V |last5=Bharti |first5=V.S |last6=Purvaja |first6=R }}</ref> The total mangrove area in Mumbai is 50 km<sup>2</sup>.<ref name="India State Forest Report, 2015"/> Mumbai's single largest mangrove belt is the western bank of [[Thane Creek]]. An extensive area of mangroves has been conserved by Soonabai Pirojsha Godrej Marine Ecology Centre, Vikhroli, Mumbai.<ref>http://www.mangroves.godrej.com/{{full citation needed|date=December 2017}}</ref>
===== Baratang Island mangroves ===== The [[Baratang Island]] mangroves are located within the [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]]. The mangrove swamps of Baratang Island are situated between [[Middle Andaman Island|Middle]] and [[South Andaman Island]].<ref name="walkthroughindiaTop5_forest"/>
====Indo-Malaya Ecozone==== Mangroves occur on Asia's south coast, throughout the Indian subcontinent, in all [[Southeast Asia]]n countries, and on islands in the Indian Ocean, [[Persian gulf]], [[Arabian Sea]], [[Bay of Bengal]], [[South China Sea]], [[East China Sea]] and the Pacific.
The mangal is particularly prevalent in the deltas of large Asian rivers. The [[Sundarbans]] is the largest mangrove forest in the world, located in the Ganges River delta in [[Bangladesh]] and [[West Bengal]], [[India]].
The Pichavaram mangroves in [[Tamil Nadu]] is India's one of the largest mangrove forests. The [[Bhitarkanika Mangroves]] Forest of Odisha, by the Bay of Bengal, is India's second largest mangrove forest.{{Citation needed|reason=claim|date=September 2014}} Other major mangals occur on the [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]] and the [[Gulf of Kutch]] in Gujarat.<ref>[http://www.mangroveindia.org/ Mangroves of India] – URL retrieved November 26, 2006</ref>
Mangroves occur in certain muddy swampy islands of the [[Maldives]].<ref>[[Xavier Romero-Frias]], ''The Maldive Islanders, A Study of the Popular Culture of an Ancient Ocean Kingdom''. Barcelona 1999, {{ISBN|84-7254-801-5}}.{{page needed|date=December 2017}}</ref>
On the [[Malayan Peninsula]] mangroves cover an estimated {{Convert|1089.7|sqkm|sqmi|1}}, while most of the remaining {{Convert|5320|sqkm|sqmi|0}} mangroves in [[Malaysia]] are on the [[Borneo|island of Borneo]].<ref>{{Cite news|author=Augustin, Sean|date=15 September 2014|title=Mangroves protect Malaysia’s coast, but also shield illegals|newspaper=The Rakyat Post|location=Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia|url=http://www.therakyatpost.com/news/2014/09/15/mangroves-protect-malaysias-coast-also-shield-illegals/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140915011230/http://www.therakyatpost.com/news/2014/09/15/mangroves-protect-malaysias-coast-also-shield-illegals/|archivedate=15 September 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
In [[Vietnam]], mangrove forests grow along the southern coast, including two forests: the [[Can Gio Mangrove Forest]] [[biosphere reserve]] and the [[U Minh Thuong National Park|U Minh mangrove forest]] in the sea and coastal region of [[Kiên Giang Province|Kiên Giang]], [[Cà Mau Province|Cà Mau]] and [[Bạc Liêu Province|Bạc Liêu]] provinces.
The mangrove forests of Kompong Sammaki in [[Cambodia]] are of major ecological and cultural importance, as the human population relies heavily on the crabs and fish that live in the roots.
The three most important mangrove forests of [[Taiwan]] are: [[Tamsui River]] in Taipei, Jhonggang River in Miaoli and the [[Sihcao Wetlands]] in [[Tainan]]. According to research, four main types of mangrove exist in Taiwan.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fan |first1=K.C. |title=Mangroves in Taiwan: current status and restoration projects. |url=http://bft.cirad.fr/cd/BFT_273_43-54.pdf}}</ref> Some places have been developed as scenic areas, such as the [[Timber rafting|log raft]] routes in Sihcao.
The most extensive mangrove forests of the [[Ryukyu Islands]] in East China Sea occur on [[Iriomote Island]] of the [[Yaeyama Islands]], [[Okinawa]], [[Japan]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Nakasuga, Tsuneo | title = Analysis of the mangrove stand (Department of Forestry) |url = http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110000220076 |publisher = University of the Ryukyus |accessdate = 2015-08-19 }}</ref> Seven types of mangroves are recognised on Iriomote Island.<ref>{{cite web |title = Iriomote Island and the Iriomote Wildcat |url = http://web-japan.org/atlas/nature/nat22.html| publisher = Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) |accessdate = 2015-08-19 }}</ref>
The northern limit of mangrove forests in the Indo-Malaya ecozone is considered to be [[Tanegashima Island]], [[Kyushu]], Japan.<ref>{{cite web |author=Somiya, Kazuo |title = Conservation of landscape and culture in southwestern islands of Japan |format=PDF |url = http://acoms.kisti.re.kr/notReviewEpaperFile.do?method=finalDown&journalSeq=J000028&issueSeq=351&serviceEpaperSeq=1649 | publisher = Naha Nature Conservation Office, Ministry of the Environment | accessdate = 2015-08-19 }}</ref>
=====Indonesia===== In the [[List of islands of Indonesia|Indonesian Archipelago]], mangroves occur around much of [[Western New Guinea|Papua province]], [[Sumatra]], [[Borneo]], [[Sulawesi]], [[Maluku Islands|Maluku]] and the surrounding islands. Further north, they are found along the coast of the [[Malay Peninsula]]. Indonesia has around 9.36 million hectares of mangrove forests, but 48% is categorized as 'moderately damaged' and 23% as 'badly damaged'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/08/07/71-indonesian-mangrove-forests-damaged-minister.html |title=71% of Indonesian mangrove forests damaged: minister |work=The Jakarta Post |accessdate=2012-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118061854/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/08/07/71-indonesian-mangrove-forests-damaged-minister.html |archivedate=2012-01-18 |df= }}</ref>
====Pakistan==== [[File:GWR 2013- Certificate.jpg|thumb|upright|The Guinness World Record certificate of achievement to Sindh Forest Department, Govt of Sindh, Pakistan]] Pakistani mangroves are located mainly along the [[Indus River Delta|delta]] of the [[Indus River]] (the [[Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea mangroves]] [[ecoregion]]). Major mangrove forests are found on the coastline of the provinces of [[Sindh]] and [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]].
In [[Karachi]], land reclamation projects have led to the cutting down of mangrove forests for commercial and urban development. On 22 June 2013, Sindh Forest Department, Govt. of Sindh, Pakistan, with the help of 300 local coastal volunteer planters set the Guinness World Record by planting 847,250 mangrove saplings at Kharo Chan, Thatta, Sindh, Pakistan in a little over 12 hours. This is the highest number of saplings planted within a day under the Guinness World Record category of "Maximum Number of Trees Planted in a Day".
Sindh Forest Department, Government of Sindh Mangrove has played pioneer role for the conservation and protection of the mangroves in the Indus Delta since late 1950s when it was handed over the areas. A breakthrough success is the re-introduction of ''[[Rhizophora mucronata]]'' into the Indus Delta, which had become extinct there. More recently, a threatened mangrove shrub, ''[[Ceriops tagal]]'', has also been successfully re-introduced. A third species, ''[[Aegiceras corniculatum]]'', is under trials at the nursery stage.
A gigantic initiative is under in the Sindh, Pakistan, to rehabilitate the degraded and blank mangrove mudflats. Since 2010 alone, around 55,000 Hectares of such area has been planted and rehabilitated. During this period, through concerted efforts and a rigorous conservation policy adopted by the Sindh Forest Department, Govt. of Sindh and the federal govt. a mangrove resource base of 150,000 plus Hectares has been created, with the support of local coastal communities. International organizations like IUCN and WWF are also playing critical role to support this initiative of the government. Other achievements include: (1) Declaring all the mangrove forests in the Indus Delta as Protected Forests in December 2010; Constitution of a Mangrove Conservation Committee at the provincial level which includes all stakeholders as members and overall awareness of the importance of mangroves and its ecosystem.<ref name="Mangrove Planting">{{cite news |url=http://pakagri.blogspot.com/2013/06/by-planting-750000-mangroves-pakistan.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130624220628/http://pakagri.blogspot.com/2013/06/by-planting-750000-mangroves-pakistan.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 June 2013 | title=By planting 750,000 mangroves, Pakistan claims new world record. | date=22 June 2013 | publisher=[[Express Tribune]] |accessdate=23 June 2013}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="110px"> File:Newly planted mangroves.jpg|Shah Bundar, Sujawal, Pakistan, new mangrove plantation File:Young mangrove plantation in the Indus Delta.jpg|A young mangrove plantation in the Indus Delta File:Mangroves along Karachi Coast.jpg|Flourishing mangroves along Karachi coast, Pakistan File:Mangrove-Keti Bundar.jpg|Glowing mangrove plantation at Keti Bundar, Thatta, Pakistan </gallery>
====Iran==== Mangrove forests are present in [[Iran]] between 25°11′N to 27°52′N, in the northern parts of the [[Persian Gulf]] and [[Sea of Oman]]. Pockets of the biome extend (from southwest to southeast) along the shores of the maritime provinces [[Bushehr]], [[Hormozgan]], and [[Sistan and Balouchestan]].
Forests on and near the island of [[Qeshm]] in the Persian Gulf are dominated by the species ''[[Avicennia marina]]'', known locally as the "hara" or "harra" tree, and cover an area of approximately 20 km by 20 km. This area is protected as the UNESCO [[Mangrove forests of Qeshm|Hara Biosphere Reserve]], where commercial use is restricted to fishing (mainly [[shrimp]]), tourist boat trips, and limited mangrove cutting for animal feed.
====Middle East==== Oman, near Muscat, supports large areas of mangroves, in particular at Shinas, Qurm Park and Mahout Island. In Arabic, mangrove trees are known as ''qurm'', thus the mangrove area in Oman is known as Qurm Park. A small mangrove area is present in the Kingdom of Bahrain. Mangroves are also present extensively in neighbouring Yemen.<ref>Rouphael, Tony ;Turak, Emre and Brodie, Jon (1992) [https://web.archive.org/web/20090919204110/http://www.actfr.jcu.edu.au/idc/groups/public/documents/journal_article/jcudev_015628.pdf "Chapter 3: Seagrasses and Mangroves of Yemen's Red Sea"] In DouAbal, A. et al. (editors) (1992) ''Protection of Marine Ecosystems of the Red Sea Coast of Yemen'' Global Environment Facility, United Nations Development Programme, New York, pp. 41–49</ref>
Mangrove is also widely seen in Tarut Island, east of Qatif in Saudi Arabia. In addition, large forest of mangrove surround the coast to the south of Qatif (Siahat Beach). Nonetheless, because of sea land re-claiming the mangrove is being cut down which makes lots of sea fish losses their natural habitats.
The mangrove forests that cover thousands of hectares of land along the UAE shoreline form an integral part of its coastal ecosystem. The [[Environment Agency Abu Dhabi|Environment Agency – Abu Dhabi (EAD)]] is currently working on rehabilitation, conservation and protection of mangrove forests in seven key sites in Abu Dhabi including: Saadiyat Island, Jubail Island, Marawah Marine Biosphere Reserve (which also comprises famous Bu Tinah Island), Bu Syayeef Protected Area, Ras Gharab, the Eastern Corniche and Ras Ghanada.
===Oceania=== ====Australia and New Guinea==== {{main|Australian mangroves}} Australia and Papua New Guinea both rank in the top five mangrove holding nations globally.<ref name="Hamilton 2018 497–520">{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-73016-5_22|title=Threats to Mangrove Forests|last=Hamilton|first=Stuart E.|last2=Castellanos-Galindo|first2=Gustavo A.|last3=Millones-Mayer|first3=Marco|last4=Chen|first4=Mara|date=2018|publisher=Springer, Cham|isbn=9783319730158|series=Coastal Research Library|pages=497–520|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-73016-5_22}}</ref> More than five species of Rhizophoraceae grow in [[Australasia]],<ref name="FAO-2007">{{cite book|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) |year=2007 |title=The world's mangroves, 1980–2005: a thematic study in the framework of the Global Forest Resources Assessment 2005 (FAO forestry paper #153(FAO) Rome |url={{google books|plainurl=y|id=tLdlpOiuSmEC|page=37}} |page =37 |isbn=978-92-5-105856-5}}</ref> with particularly high biodiversity on the [[island of New Guinea]] and northern Australia.<ref name="FAO-2007"/>
As of 2012 Australia has slightly below 1 million ha of mangrove <ref name="Hamilton 2018 497–520"/> and Papua New Guinea has just under approximately 500,000 ha +- 12% (CI 0.9, n = 7) of mangrove.<ref name="Hamilton 2018 497–520"/>
====New Zealand==== [[New Zealand]] also has mangrove forests extending to around 38°S (similar to Australia's latitudinal limit): the southernmost examples are at [[Raglan, New Zealand|Raglan Harbour]] (37°48′S) on the west coast and Ohiwa Harbour (near [[Opotiki]], 38°00′S) on the east coast.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} ''[[Avicennia marina]] australasica'' is the only mangrove in New Zealand.
====Pacific islands==== Twenty-five species of mangrove are found on various Pacific islands, with extensive mangals on some islands. Mangals on [[Guam]], [[Palau]], [[Kosrae]] and [[Yap]] have been badly affected by development.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://biology.usgs.gov/s+t/SNT/noframe/pi179.htm |title=Hawaii and the Pacific Islands |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060927144136/http://biology.usgs.gov/s%2Bt/SNT/noframe/pi179.htm |archivedate=September 27, 2006 |author=Lloyd L. Loope |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]}}</ref>
Mangroves are not native to [[Hawaii]], but the red mangrove, ''[[Rhizophora mangle]]'', and Oriental mangrove, ''[[Bruguiera sexangula]]'', have been introduced and are now [[Naturalisation (biology)|naturalized]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Allen, James A. |author2=Krauss, Ken W. |lastauthoramp=yes |date=2006 |title=Influence of propagule flotation longevity and light availability on establishment of introduced mangrove species in Hawai'i |journal=[[Pacific Science]] |volume=60 |issue=3 |pages=367–376 |url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/pacific_science/toc/psc60.3.html |doi=10.1353/psc.2006.0015 |hdl=10125/22572}}</ref> Both species are considered [[invasive species]] and classified as pests by the [[University of Hawaii]] Botany Department.<ref>[http://www.botany.hawaii.edu/faculty/cw_smith/aliens.htm Hawaiian Alien Plant Studies] – URL retrieved November 28, 2006.</ref>
==Mangroves around the world== <gallery widths="150px" heights="120px" class="center"> File:Mangrove park.JPG|Mangrove Park in [[Kannur]], India File:Sihcao Green Tunnel.JPG|Sihcao, [[Tainan]], [[Taiwan]] File:Mangrove knees Yap.jpg|[[Yap]], Micronesia File:Pichavaram mangrove forest panorama.jpg|[[Pichavaram]], India File:Mangrove swamp, Iriomote Island, Okinawa, Japan.jpg|[[Iriomote Island]], Japan </gallery>
==Exploitation and conservation== [[Image:Arrière-mangrove de Majicavo janvier 2017.jpg|thumb|Mangrove roots act as a net retaining waste and trash, hence accumulating pollution. Here in [[Mayotte]] at low tide.]] [[File:Bali Barat mangroves.jpg|thumb|Mangroves in [[West Bali National Park]], Indonesia.]]
Adequate data are only available for about half of the global area of mangroves. However, of those areas for which data has been collected, it appears that 35% of the mangroves have been destroyed.<ref>Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (2005) ''Ecosystems and Human Well-being: Synthesis'' (p.2) Island Press, Washington, DC. World Resources Institute {{ISBN|1-59726-040-1}}</ref> The [[United Nations Environment Programme]] and Hamilton (2013), estimate that [[shrimp farming]] causes approximately a quarter of the destruction of mangrove forests.<ref>Botkin, D. and E. Keller (2003) ''Environmental Science: Earth as a living planet'' (p.2) John Wiley & Sons. {{ISBN|0-471-38914-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.5343/bms.2012.1069 |title=Assessing the Role of Commercial Aquaculture in Displacing Mangrove Forest |journal=Bulletin of Marine Science |volume=89 |issue=2 |pages=585–601 |year=2013 |last1=Hamilton |first1=Stuart }}</ref> Likewise, the 2010 update of the World Mangrove Atlas indicated that approximately one fifth of the world's mangrove ecosystems have been lost since 1980,<ref name="nature.org">{{cite web|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100717013054/http://www.nature.org/pressroom/press/press4573.html|archive-date= 2010-07-17|url=http://www.nature.org/pressroom/press/press4573.html |title= 2010a. ""World Atlas of Mangroves" Highlights the Importance of and Threats to Mangroves: Mangroves among World's Most Valuable Ecosystems." Press release. Arlington, Virginia |publisher=The Nature Conservancy|accessdate=2014-01-25|deadurl= yes}}</ref> although this rapid loss rate appears to have decreased since 2000 with global losses estimated at between 0.16% and 0.39% annually between 2000 and 2012.<ref name=":2" /> Despite global loss rates decreasing since 2000, Southeast Asia remains an area of concern with loss rates between 3.58% and 8.08% between 2000 and 2012.<ref name=":2" />
Grassroots efforts to save mangroves from development are becoming more popular as their benefits become more widely known. In the [[Bahamas]], for example, active efforts to save mangroves are occurring on the islands of [[Bimini]] and [[Great Guana Cay]]. In [[Trinidad and Tobago]] as well, efforts are underway to protect a mangrove threatened by the construction of a steelmill and a port.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In Thailand, community management has been effective in restoring damaged mangroves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ecotippingpoints.org/our-stories/indepth/thailand-mangrove-restoration-community-management.html |title=Thailand – Trang Province – Taking Back the Mangroves with Community Management | The EcoTipping Points Project |publisher=Ecotippingpoints.org |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref> Within northern Ecuador mangrove regrowth is reported in almost all estuaries and stems primarily from local actors responding to earlier periods of deforestation in the Esmeraldas region.<ref name="mingaonline.uach.cl"/>
Mangroves have been reported to be able to help buffer against [[tsunami]], [[cyclone]]s, and other storms. One village in [[Tamil Nadu]] was protected from tsunami destruction—the villagers in [[Naluvedapathy]] planted 80,244 saplings to get into the [[Guinness Book of World Records]]. This created a kilometre-wide belt of trees of various varieties. When the tsunami struck, much of the land around the village was flooded, but the village itself suffered minimal damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treecouncil.org.uk |title=Tree News, Spring/Summer 2005, Publisher Felix Press |publisher=Treecouncil.org.uk |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref>
==Reforestation== [[File:Mangroves of Bohol.png|thumb|Mangroves in [[Bohol]], Philippines.]]
In some areas, mangrove reforestation and [[mangrove restoration]] is also underway. Red mangroves are the most common choice for cultivation, used particularly in [[marine aquariums]] in a [[sump]] to reduce [[nitrates]] and other [[nutrients]] in the water. Mangroves also appear in home [[aquariums]], and as ornamental plants, such as in [[Japan]].
In Senegal, [[Haïdar El Ali]] has started the {{Il|fr|Oceanium de Dakar}} project, which (amongst others) focuses on reforesting several areas with mangroves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oceanium.blogspot.com/ |title=Oceanium de Dakar |publisher=Oceanium.blogspot.com |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref>
The Manzanar Mangrove Initiative is an ongoing experiment in [[Arkiko]], [[Eritrea]], part of the Manzanar Project founded by [[Gordon H. Sato]], establishing new mangrove plantations on the coastal [[mudflat]]s. Initial plantings failed, but observation of the areas where mangroves did survive by themselves led to the conclusion that nutrients in water flow from inland were important to the health of the mangroves. Trials with the Eritrean Ministry of Fisheries followed, and a planting system was designed to provide the nitrogen, phosphorus, and iron missing from seawater.<ref name="NatGeo2007-02"/><ref name="SocWetlandSci"/>
The propagules are planted inside a reused galvanized steel can with the bottom knocked out; a small piece of iron and a pierced plastic bag with fertilizer containing nitrogen and phosphorus are buried with the propagule. {{As of|2007}}, after six years of planting, 700,000 mangroves are growing; providing stock feed for sheep and habitat for oysters, crabs, other bivalves, and fish.<ref name="NatGeo2007-02">{{cite web | last = Warne | first = Kennedy | others = Tim Laman, photographer | title = Mangroves: Forests of the Tide | work = National Geographic | publisher = National Geographic Society | date = February 2007 | url = http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2007/02/mangroves/warne-text/5 | accessdate = 2010-08-08}} </ref><ref name="SocWetlandSci">{{Cite journal | last = Sato | first = Gordon | authorlink = Gordon H. Sato | author2 = Abraham Fisseha |author3=Simon Gebrekiros |author4=Hassan Abdul Karim |author5=Samuel Negassi |author6=Martin Fischer |author7=Emanuel Yemane |author8=Johannes Teclemariam |author9=Robert Riley |lastauthoramp=yes | title = A novel approach to growing mangroves on the coastal mud flats of Eritrea with the potential for relieving regional poverty and hunger | journal = Wetlands | volume = 25 | issue = 3 | pages = 776–779 | doi = 10.1672/0277-5212(2005)025[0776:ANATGM]2.0.CO;2
| year = 2005 }}</ref>
==National studies== In terms of local and national studies of mangrove loss, the case of Belize's mangroves is illustrative in its contrast to the global picture. A recent, satellite-based study<ref name="maps.cathalac.org"/>—funded by the World Wildlife Fund and conducted by the Water Center for the Humid Tropics of Latin America and the Caribbean (CATHALAC)—indicates Belize's mangrove cover declined by a mere 2% over a 30-year period. The study was born out of the need to verify the popular conception that mangrove clearing in Belize was rampant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ambergriscaye.com/pages/town/art/Pelican_Review.pdf |title=Pelican_Cays_Review |format=PDF |accessdate=2012-02-08}}</ref>
Instead, the assessment showed, between 1980 and 2010, under {{convert|4,000|acre|km2}} of mangroves had been cleared, although clearing of mangroves near Belize's main coastal settlements (e.g. [[Belize City]] and San Pedro) was relatively high. The rate of loss of Belize's mangroves—at 0.07% per year between 1980 and 2010—was much lower than Belize's overall rate of forest clearing (0.6% per year in the same period).<ref>[http://www.servir.net/servir_bz_forest_cover_1980-2010.pdf Cherrington, E.A., Ek, E., Cho, P., Howell, B.F., Hernandez, B.E., Anderson, E.R., Flores, A.I., Garcia, B.C., Sempris, E., and D.E. Irwin. 2010. "Forest Cover and Deforestation in Belize: 1980–2010." Water Center for the Humid Tropics of Latin America and the Caribbean. Panama City, Panama. 42 pp.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130729135101/http://www.servir.net/servir_bz_forest_cover_1980-2010.pdf |date=July 29, 2013 }}</ref> These findings can also be interpreted to indicate Belize's mangrove regulations (under the nation's)<ref>[http://www.belizelaw.org/lawadmin/PDF%20files/cap213s.pdf Government of Belize (GOB). 2003. "Forests Act Subsidiary Laws." Chapter 213 in: Substantive Laws of Belize. Revised Edition 2003. Government Printer: Belmopan, Belize. 137 pp.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313105434/http://www.belizelaw.org/lawadmin/PDF%20files/cap213s.pdf |date=March 13, 2012 }}</ref> have largely been effective. Nevertheless, the need to protect Belize's mangroves is imperative, as a 2009 study by the World Resources Institute (WRI) indicates the ecosystems contribute US$174–249 million per year to Belize's national economy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pdf.wri.org/working_papers/coastal_capital_belize_wp.pdf |title=Coastal Capital: Belize. The Economic Contribution of Belize's Coral Reefs and Mangroves |format=PDF |last1=Cooper |first1=E. |last2=Burke |first2=L. |last3=Bood |first3=N. |date=2009 |publisher=World Resources Institute |location=Washington, DC |accessdate=2014-06-23}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = Manufacture Modules Technologies MMT | logo = MMT SwissConnect Logo.jpg | type = [[Société à responsabilité limitée|SARL]] | key_people = Philippe Fraboulet, CEO | industry = [[Wireless]], [[Life Sciences]], [[Biotech]], [[Horology]] | foundation = 2015 | location = [[Geneva]] | homepage = {{URL |www.mmt.ch}} }}
'''Manufacture Modules Technologies Sarl''' is a Swiss company established in Geneva in 2015 and originally specialised in the development and commercialization of "Horological Smartwatch modules", firmware, apps and cloud. Located at Skylab, one of Geneva’s main high-tech hubs, it has lately expanded into the development and manufacturing of "E-Straps" operated with a mobile application.<ref name="wareable">{{Cite news|url=https://www.swissmadesoftware.org/en/companies/manufacture-modules-et-technologies-sarl/home.html|title=Manufacture Modules et Technologies Sarl|last=|first=|date=February 27, 2015|work=Swissmade Software|access-date=|via=|author=Swissmade Software|accessdate=February 27, 2015}}</ref> The company offers firmware, a cloud, manufacturing, service and over-the-air facilities for upgrades. The company also offers its own apps, which bear the label “Swiss Made software”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.worldtempus.com/article/industry-news/mmt-swiss-connect-anything-apple-can-do-2456126|title=MMT Swiss Connect Anything Apple can do…|last=|first=|date=September 8, 2016|website=WorldTempus|publisher=|access-date=September 8, 2016}}</ref>
In July 2016, Union Horlogere Holding and MMT have been spun-out of the Frédérique Constant Group.<ref name="Hodinkee">{{Cite news |title= MMT Spins Off From Frederique Constant |date=September 7, 2016 |work= Hodinkee |author=Stephen Pulvirent |url= http://www.hodinkee.com/articles/mmt-spin-off-independent-company |accessdate = September 7, 2016 }}</ref>
Philippe Fraboulet is the new CEO of MMT Swiss Connect.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hodinkee.com/articles/mmt-spin-off-independent-company|title=Business News MMT Spins Off From Frederique Constant As Its Own Combination Smartwatch/Software Company|last=Stephen Pulvirent|first=|date=September 8, 2016|website=Hodinkee|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
The initial licensees were [[Frederique Constant]], [[Alpina]] and [[Mondaine]]. Together, they offer ten different models in designer collections for both women and men.<ref name="bloomberg">{{Cite news |title= The Swiss Have Finally Started Making Luxury Smartwatches |date=February 26, 2015 |work= Bloomberg |author=Stephen Pulvirent |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-02-27/the-swiss-have-finally-started-making-luxury-smartwatches |accessdate = February 27, 2015 }}</ref> Fullpower creates and manages the circuit design, firmware, smartphone applications (including sleep activity), as well as the cloud Infrastructure. MMT manages the Swiss watch movement development and production as well as licensing and support for the Swiss watch industry.<ref name="cnet">{{Cite news |title= Swiss watches are getting smart without sacrificing style |date=February 26, 2015 |work= CNET |author= Sarah Mitroff |url= http://www.cnet.com/news/swiss-watches-are-getting-smart-without-sacrificing-style/ |accessdate = February 27, 2015 }}</ref><ref name="“Forbes">{{Cite news |title= Tag Heuer Signals Start Of Swiss Smartwatch Revolution |date=March 19, 2015 |work= Forbes |author= Paul Lamkin |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/paullamkin/2015/03/19/tag-heuer-signals-start-of-swiss-smartwatch-revolution// |accessdate = March 20, 2015 }}</ref>
Manufacture Module Technologies Sarl Fullpower Technologies Inc. 19.99% share was acquired by Union Horlogere Holding BV, giving it 100% of shares in MMT.<ref name="Chamber of Commerce">{{Cite news|url=http://ge.ch/hrcintapp/externalCompanyReport.action?companyOfsUid=CHE-483.454.783&lang=FR|title=Extract MMT|date=September 8, 2016|author=Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=September 7, 2016}}</ref>

{{Infobox university | name = Marymount California University | image = Marymount College PV.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Entrance to the campus | motto = ''Tua Luce Dirige'' | mottoeng = Direct Us by Thy Light | established = 1932 | type = [[Private School|Private]] [[Liberal arts colleges in the United States|liberal arts college]] | president = Brian Marcotte | city = [[Rancho Palos Verdes, California|Rancho Palos Verdes]] | affiliation = [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]]
([[Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary]]) | state = [[California]] | country = USA | enrollment = 1,000 | campus = [[Suburban]], {{convert|26|acre|ha}} | colors = Blue {{Color box|#05329D|border=darkgray}} and {{Color box|#FEFEFE|border=darkgray}} White | nickname = [http://www.marinerathletics.com/ Mariners] | athletics = [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] – [[California Pacific Conference|Cal-Pac]] | affiliations = [[Association of Catholic Colleges and Universities|ACCU]][http://www.accunet.org/files/public/~ACCU%20Members%20List(1).pdf ACCU Member Institutions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714191013/http://www.accunet.org/files/public/~ACCU%20Members%20List%281%29.pdf |date=2014-07-14 }}
[[Council of Independent Colleges|CIC]] | website = [http://www.marymountcalifornia.edu/ www.marymountcalifornia.edu] | picture = }} '''Marymount California University''' is a [[Catholicism|Catholic]], [[Mixed-sex education|coeducational]] [[university]] in [[Rancho Palos Verdes, California|Rancho Palos Verdes]], [[California]]. Based in the liberal arts tradition and inspired by the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary (RHSM), the university awards [[associate degree|associate]], [[bachelor's]], and [[graduate degree]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.marymountcalifornia.edu/academic-programs|title=Academic Program Information - Marymount California University|website=Marymountcalifornia.edu|accessdate=13 August 2018}} The institution is [[Higher education accreditation|accredited]] by the [[Western Association of Schools and Colleges]].{{cite web|url=https://www.wascsenior.org/institutions/marymount-california-university|title=Marymount California University - WASC Senior College and University Commission|website=Wascsenior.org|accessdate=13 August 2018}} ==History== Marymount California University was established in 1968 by the RHSM as Marymount Palos Verdes College. It was split from the original Marymount College in [[Westwood, Los Angeles, California|Westwood, Los Angeles]]; this Marymount later merged with St. Joseph's College and then Loyola University to form [[Loyola Marymount University]]. At the time, the college was a two-year institution of higher education. In 1975, responsibility for the College was transferred to a lay board of trustees.{{cite web|url=http://www.marymountcalifornia.edu/?q=quick-facts|title=Quick Facts - Marymount California University|website=Marymountcalifornia.edu|accessdate=13 August 2018}} In 1986, the college changed its name from Marymount Palos Verdes College to Marymount College. In summer 2011, Marymount opened its Waterfront Campus in downtown [[San Pedro, Los Angeles]].[http://www.dailybreeze.com/moresanpedro/ci_18680236?source=email] {{dead link|date=August 2018}} In spring 2013, Marymount changed its name from Marymount College to Marymount California University to reflect "an ongoing transformation of the 45-year-old institution of higher education to a multi-campus institution offering undergraduate and graduate degree programs." In fall 2013, Marymount opened its Lakeside Campus in the community of Lucerne in rural Lake County, in Northern California.{{cite web |url=http://www.the-tidings.com/index.php/features/san-pedro/3282-marymount-college-changes-name-to-reflect-growth-mission |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407074951/http://www.the-tidings.com/index.php/features/san-pedro/3282-marymount-college-changes-name-to-reflect-growth-mission |archivedate=2014-04-07 |df= }} In February 2018, the university appointed trustee Brian Marcotte its new president. It was not immediately clear why the previous president, Lucas Lamadrid, left the position although the local newspaper ''[[Daily Breeze]]'' reported "allegations of inappropriate behavior, exorbitant spending and discriminatory conduct."{{cite web |url=https://www.dailybreeze.com/2018/02/05/marymount-california-university-president-mia-amid-allegations-of-inappropriate-behavior/ |title= Marymount California University president MIA amid allegations of inappropriate behavior |author=Valerie Osier |publisher=[[Daily Breeze]] |date=February 5, 2018 |accessdate=February 12, 2018}} ==Campuses== The '''Oceanview Campus''' encompasses 26-acres overlooking the Pacific Ocean and [[Santa Catalina Island, California|Catalina Island]] in Rancho Palos Verdes.{{cite web |url=http://californiacolleges.edu/campustour/undergraduate/376/Marymount_College__CA/Marymount_College__CA8.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402161736/http://californiacolleges.edu/campustour/undergraduate/376/Marymount_College__CA/Marymount_College__CA8.html |archivedate=2012-04-02 |df= }} The '''Waterfront Campus''' encompasses the first floor of the former [[Northrop Grumman]] facility at 222 W. Sixth St., and provides classroom and studio space for upper division students, as well as some office space for [[Business school|faculty and staff]]. '''Residential Community''' include The Villas located in adjacent San Pedro, a community of fully furnished, two-story townhomes that can accommodate 400 students and staff. In the center of the community is a swimming pool, fitness center, outdoor covered pavilion, beach volleyball court, basketball court and a soon to be completed outdoor kitchen.{{cite web |url=http://www.marymountcalifornia.edu/san-pedro-residential |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140403163124/http://www.marymountcalifornia.edu/san-pedro-residential |archivedate=2014-04-03 |df= }} '''Free Shuttle Service''' is available for all enrolled students, faculty and staff between all of our Southern California campuses, as well as a number of other sites around the community.{{cite web|url=http://www.marymountcalifornia.edu/transportation|title=Campus Shuttle and Transportation - Marymount California University|website=Marymountcalifornia.edu|accessdate=13 August 2018}} ==Academics== Marymount California University is accredited by the [[Western Association of Schools and Colleges|WASC]] Senior College and University Commission. Marymount California University offers the following undergraduate degree programs: * Associate in Arts * Associate in Science * Bachelor of Arts in Business * Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts * Bachelor of Arts in Media Studies * Bachelor of Arts in Psychology * Bachelor of Arts in Criminal Justice Marymount California University offers the following graduate degree programs: * Master of Business Administration * Master of Science in Community Psychology * Master of Science in Leadership and Global Development ==Student Body== *Total Undergraduate Enrollment:1,099 *Female: 54% *Out of State: 6% *[[International student|International]]: 19% *[[Freshman]] Enrollment: 438 {{cite web|url=http://www.princetonreview.com/schools/college/CollegeBasics.aspx?iid=1025388|title=Marymount California University - The Princeton Review College Rankings & Reviews|website=Princetonreview.com|accessdate=13 August 2018}} *Student/Faculty Ratio: 17:1 ==Athletics== Marymount California University teams, nicknamed the Mariners, are part of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA) and compete in the California Pacific Conference (CalPac).{{cite web|url=http://www.calpacathletics.com/f/About_The_CalPac.php|title=About the Cal Pac|website=California Pacific Conference|accessdate=13 August 2018}} Men's and women's sports include cross country, golf, lacrosse, soccer, softball, baseball, track and women's indoor/beach volleyball.{{cite web|url=http://www.marinerathletics.com/|title=Marymount California University Athletics|website=Marinerathletics.com|accessdate=13 August 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.marymountcalifornia.edu/}} *[http://www.marinerathletics.com Official athletics website] {{Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles}} {{Palos Verdes}} {{Colleges and universities in Los Angeles County}} {{California Pacific Conference navbox}} {{College Sports in California}} {{Women's colleges that became coeducational}} {{Coord|33.735217|N|118.333783|W|type:edu_region:US-CA|display=title}} [[Category:Liberal arts colleges]] [[Category:Palos Verdes Peninsula]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Catholic universities and colleges in the United States]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1932]] [[Category:Schools accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges]] [[Category:Former women's universities and colleges in the United States]] [[Category:Catholic universities and colleges in California]] [[Category:Association of Catholic Colleges and Universities]] [[Category:California Pacific Conference schools]]

M. Keck Observatory|Keck Observatory]] |telescope10_type = 2x10 m visible/infrared telescopes |telescope11_name = [[UH88]] |telescope11_type = 2.2 m visible/infrared |telescope12_name = UH Hilo Hoku Ke'a Telescope |telescope12_type = 0.9 m visible }}
The '''Mauna Kea Observatories''' ('''MKO''') are a number of independent astronomical research facilities and large telescope observatories that are located at the summit of [[Mauna Kea]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island of Hawaiʻi]], [[United States]]. The facilities are located in a 525-acre (212 ha) special land use zone known as the "Astronomy Precinct", which is located within the 11,228-acre (4,544 ha) Mauna Kea Science Reserve.<ref name=uhero>{{cite web|title=The Economic Impact of Astronomy in Hawai‘i|url=http://www.uhero.hawaii.edu/assets/UHERO_Astronomy_Final.pdf|publisher=University of Hawaii Economic Research Organization|accessdate=14 July 2015|date=28 August 2014}}</ref> The Astronomy Precinct was established in 1967 and is located on land protected by the [[National Historic Preservation Act of 1966|Historical Preservation Act]] for its significance to Hawaiian culture.
The location is near ideal because of its: * [[light pollution|dark skies]] from lack of light pollution, * good [[astronomical seeing]], * low [[Relative humidity|humidity]], * high altitude of {{convert|4,205|meter}}, * position above most of the water vapor in the atmosphere, * clean air, * good weather and * low latitude location.<ref name="About Mauna Kea Observatories">[http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/mko/about_maunakea.htm About Mauna Kea Observatories]</ref>
==Origin and background== After studying photos for [[NASA]]'s [[Apollo program]] that contained greater detail than any ground-based telescope, [[Gerard Kuiper]] began seeking an arid site for infrared studies.<ref name="Zirker2005" /><ref name="Inc.1964">{{cite book|author=Educational Foundation for Nuclear Science, Inc.|title=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8gcAAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA35|date=November 1964|publisher=Educational Foundation for Nuclear Science, Inc.|page=35|issn=0096-3402}}</ref> While he first began looking in Chile, he also made the decision to perform tests in the Hawaiian Islands. Tests on [[Maui]]'s [[Haleakalā]] were promising, but the mountain was too low in the inversion layer and often covered by clouds. On the "Big Island" of Hawaiʻi, Mauna Kea is considered the highest island mountain in the world. While the summit is often covered with snow, the air is extremely dry.<ref name="Zirker2005" /> Kuiper began looking into the possibility of an observatory on Mauna Kea. After testing, he discovered the low humidity was perfect for infrared signals. He persuaded Hawaiʻi Governor [[John A. Burns]] to bulldoze a dirt road to the summit where he built a small telescope on Pu{{okina}}u Poli{{okina}}ahu, a cinder cone peak.<ref name="Zirker2005" /><ref name="Yount1996">{{cite book|author=David Yount|title=Who Runs the University?: The Politics of Higher Education in Hawaii, 1985-1992|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZtnBE9CcxOAC&pg=PA232|date=1 January 1996|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-1821-0|page=232}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Astronomy Now|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CB7yAAAAMAAJ|date=1991|publisher=Intra Press|page=45}}</ref> The peak was the second highest on the mountain with the highest peak being holy ground, so Kuiper avoided it.<ref name="PARKER2013">{{cite book|author=Barry R. PARKER|title=Stairway to the Stars: The Story of the World’s Largest Observatory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RbkACAAAQBAJ&pg=PA25|date=11 November 2013|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4899-6052-8}}</ref>{{rp|25}} Next, Kuiper tried enlisting NASA to fund a larger facility with a large telescope, housing and other needed structures. NASA, in turn decided to make the project open to competition. Professor of physics, John Jefferies of the [[University of Hawaii]] placed a bid on behalf of the university.<ref name="Zirker2005" /><ref name="Leverington2012">{{cite book|author=David Leverington|title=A History of Astronomy: from 1890 to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r47qBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA276|date=6 December 2012|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4471-2124-4|page=276}}</ref><ref name="KaminsPotter1998">{{cite book|author1=Robert M. Kamins|author2=Robert E. Potter|author3=University of Hawaii (System)|title=Måalamalama: A History of the University of Hawaiʻi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8jyzfUmFvgC&pg=PA211|date=January 1998|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-2006-0|pages=210–211}}</ref> Jefferies had gained his reputation through observations at [[National Solar Observatory#Sacramento Peak|Sacramento Peak Observatory]]. The proposal was for a two-meter telescope to serve both the needs of NASA and the university. While large telescopes are not ordinarily awarded to universities without well-established astronomers, Jefferies and UH were awarded the NASA contract, infuriating Kuiper, who felt that "his mountain" had been "stolen" from ''him''.<ref name="Zirker2005" /><ref name="Tatarewicz1990">{{cite book|author=Joseph N. Tatarewicz|title=Space Technology & Planetary Astronomy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MnXQtlBcRFIC&pg=PA82|date=1990|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0-253-35655-5|page=82}}</ref> Kuiper would abandon his site (the very first telescope on Mauna Kea) over the competition and begin work in Arizona on a different NASA project. After considerable testing by Jefferies' team, the best locations were determined to be near the summit at the top of the cinder cones. Testing also determined Mauna Kea to be superb for nighttime viewing due to many factors, including the thin air, constant trade winds and being surrounded by sea. Jefferies would build a 2.24 meter telescope with the State of Hawaiʻi agreeing to build a reliable, all weather roadway to the summit. Building began in 1967 and first light was seen in 1970.<ref name="Zirker2005">{{cite book|author=J. B. Zirker|title=An Acre of Glass: A History and Forecast of the Telescope|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TYYVXIePsy4C&pg=PA94|date=18 October 2005|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-8234-0|pages=89–95}}</ref>
Other groups began requesting subleases on the newly accessible mountaintop. By 1970, two {{convert|24|in|m|1|abbr=on}} telescopes had been constructed by the [[United States Air Force]] and [[Lowell Observatory]]. In 1973, Canada and France agreed to build the 3.6 m [[Canada–France–Hawaii Telescope|CFHT]] on Mauna Kea.<ref name="astro-timeline">{{cite web|title=Timeline of Astronomy in Hawaiʻi|url=http://mkooc.org/css-timeline.html|publisher=Mauna Kea Observatories Outreach Committee|accessdate=October 2, 2010|first=Andrew|last=Pickles|date=2003|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727090520/http://mkooc.org/css-timeline.html|archivedate=July 27, 2011|df=}}</ref> However, local organizations started to raise concerns about the environmental impact of the observatory. This led the Department of Land and Natural Resources to prepare an initial management plan, drafted in 1977 and supplemented in 1980. In January 1982, the University of Hawaiʻi [[Governing boards of colleges and universities in the United States|Board of Regents]] approved a plan to support the continued development of scientific facilities at the site.<ref name="uh-2009"/> In 1998, {{convert|2033|acre|ha|0|abbr=on}} were transferred from the observatory lease to supplement the Mauna Kea Ice Age Reserve. The 1982 plan was replaced in 2000 by an extension designed to serve until 2020: it instituted an [[Office of Mauna Kea Management]],<ref name="uh-2000">{{cite web|title=Mauna Kea Science Reserve Astronomy Development Plan 2000–2020 – Summary |url=http://www.hawaii.edu/maunakea/appendix_a.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s9ktvOST?url=http://www.hawaii.edu/maunakea/appendix_a.pdf |archivedate=August 21, 2010 |format=PDF |publisher=[[Institute for Astronomy]] – [[University of Hawaii]] |accessdate=August 19, 2010 |date=August 1999 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> designated {{convert|525|acre|ha|0|abbr=on}} for astronomy, and shifted the remaining {{convert|10763|acre|ha|0|abbr=on}} to "natural and cultural preservation". This plan was further revised to address concern expressed in the Hawaiian community that a lack of respect was being shown toward the cultural values of the mountain.<ref name="uh-2009">{{cite web|title=Mauna Kea Comprehensive Management Plan: UH Management Areas|url=http://archive.jan2013.hawaii.gov/dlnr/occl/mauna-kea-management-plan/comprehensive-management-plan|format=PDF|author=[[Institute for Astronomy]] – [[University of Hawaii]]|publisher=Hawai`i State Department of Land and Natural Resources|accessdate=August 19, 2010|date=January 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304045751/http://archive.jan2013.hawaii.gov/dlnr/occl/mauna-kea-management-plan/comprehensive-management-plan|archivedate=March 4, 2016|df=}}</ref>
{{As of|2012}}, the Mauna Kea Science Reserve has 13 observation facilities, each funded by as many as 11 countries. It is one of the world's premier observatories for optical, infrared, and submillimeter astronomy, <!---ref has not been updated, other observatories now numerically more telescopes'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/mko/|title=Mauna Kea Observatories|publisher=University of Hawaii Institute for Astronomy|accessdate=January 18, 2012}}</ref><---> and in 2009 was the largest measured by light gathering power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.jan2013.hawaii.gov/dlnr/occl/random-files/mauna-kea-files/Mauna_Kea_CMP-Sect5-7.pdf|title=Mauna Kea Comprehensive Management Plan|author=University of Hawai`i|date=January 2009|publisher=Hawai`i State Department of Land and Natural Resources|pages=6–1|accessdate=January 18, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304071537/http://archive.jan2013.hawaii.gov/dlnr/occl/random-files/mauna-kea-files/Mauna_Kea_CMP-Sect5-7.pdf|archivedate=March 4, 2016|df=}}</ref> There are nine telescopes working in the visible and infrared spectrum, three in the submillimeter spectrum, and one in the radio spectrum, with mirrors or dishes ranging from {{convert|0.9|to|25|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="telescope-table"/> In comparison, the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] has a {{convert|2.4|m|ft|1|abbr=on}} mirror, similar in size to the UH88, now the second smallest telescope on the mountain.<ref name="telescope-table">{{cite web|title=Mauna Kea Telescopes|url=http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/mko/telescope_table.shtml|publisher=[[Institute for Astronomy]] – [[University of Hawaii]]|accessdate=August 29, 2010}}</ref> Planned new telescopes, including the [[Thirty Meter Telescope]], have attracted controversy due to their potential cultural and ecological impact.<ref name="tmt">{{cite web|title=Thirty Meter Telescope Selects Mauna Kea|url=http://www.tmt.org/news-center/thirty-meter-telescope-selects-mauna-kea|work=Press release|publisher=[[California Institute of Technology]], [[University of California]], and the Association of Canadian Universities for Research in Astronomy|accessdate=August 29, 2010|date=August 21, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100810235601/http://www.tmt.org/news-center/thirty-meter-telescope-selects-mauna-kea|archivedate=August 10, 2010|df=}}</ref><ref name="pan-starrs">{{cite web|title=University of Hawaii Develop New Telescope for "Killer" Asteroid Search|url=http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/~kaiser/pan-starrs/pressrelease/|work=Press release|publisher=[[Institute for Astronomy]] – [[University of Hawaii]]|date=October 8, 2002}}</ref> The multi-telescope "outrigger" extension to the [[W. M. Keck Observatory|Keck telescopes]], which required new sites, was eventually canceled.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ruling could block Mauna Kea projects|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/stories/2006/08/07/daily18.html?jst=b_ln_hl|accessdate=November 4, 2010|newspaper=Pacific Business News|date=August 8, 2006}}</ref> Three or four of the mountain's 13 existing telescopes must be dismantled over the next decade with the [[Thirty Meter Telescope|TMT]] proposal to be the last area on Mauna Kea on which any telescope would ever be built.<ref name="nature.com">http://www.nature.com/news/hawaii-prunes-mauna-kea-telescope-hub-1.17688</ref>
==Management== The Reserve was established in 1968, and is leased by the [[Hawai'i Department of Land and Natural Resources|State of Hawaiʻi's Department of Land and Natural Resources]] (DLNR).<ref name="burns">{{cite web |url=http://www.malamamaunakea.org/about-us/history |title=History |publisher=Office of Mauna Kea Management |accessdate=February 2, 2015}}</ref> The [[University of Hawaii|University of Hawaiʻi]] manages the site<ref name="burns"/> and leases land to several multi-national facilities, which have invested more than $2 billion in science and technology.<ref name=uhero/> The lease expires on 2033 and after that 40 of 45 square kilometers (25 of 28 square miles) revert to the state of Hawaii <ref name="nature.com"/>
==Location== [[File:Mauna Kea Observatories.jpg|alt=Mauna Kea Observatories seen from the base of Mauna Kea|thumb|Mauna Kea Observatories seen from the base of [[Mauna Kea]]]] The altitude and isolation in the middle of the [[Pacific Ocean]] makes Mauna Kea one of the best locations on earth for ground-based astronomy. It is an ideal location for submillimeter, infrared and optical observations. The [[astronomical seeing|seeing]] statistics show that Mauna Kea is the best site in terms of optical and infrared image quality; for example, the CFHT site has a median seeing of 0.43 arcseconds.
Accommodations for research astronomers are located at the [[Onizuka Center for International Astronomy]] (often called Hale Pōhaku), {{convert|7|miles}} by unpaved steep road from the summit at {{convert|9300|ft|m}} above sea level.
An adjacent visitor information station is located at {{convert|9200|ft|m}}. The summit of Mauna Kea is so high that tourists are advised to stop at the visitor station for at least 30 minutes to acclimate to atmospheric conditions before continuing to the summit, and scientists often stay at Hale Pōhaku for eight hours or more before spending a full night at observatories on the summit, with some telescopes requiring observers to spend one full night at Hale Pōhaku before working at the summit.
==Telescopes== [[File:Submillimeter Array Night.jpg|thumb|right|The Submillimeter Array of radio telescopes at night, lit by [[Flash photography|flash]].]] [[File:The Keck Subaru and Infrared obervatories.JPG|thumb|right|The Subaru Telescope, the Keck I and II Telescopes, and the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility]]
Telescopes found at the summit of Mauna Kea are funded by government agencies of various nations. The University of Hawaiʻi directly administers two telescopes. In total, there are twelve facilities housing thirteen telescopes<ref name=Telescopes>{{cite web|title=Mauna Kea Observatories|url=https://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/mko/telescope_table.shtml|website=Maunakea Telescopes|publisher=University of Hawaii Institute of Astronomy|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> at or around the summit of Mauna Kea. It may also be the site of the [[Thirty Meter Telescope]] and is a proposed site for [[Pan-STARRS]].
* [[Caltech Submillimeter Observatory]] (CSO): [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]] — closed 2015 * [[Canada–France–Hawaii Telescope|Canada–France–Hawaiʻi Telescope]] (CFHT): [[Canada]], [[France]], [[University of Hawaii|University of Hawaiʻi]] * [[Gemini Observatory|Gemini North Telescope]]: [[United States]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], [[Chile]], [[Australia]], [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]] * [[NASA Infrared Telescope Facility]] (IRTF): [[NASA]] * [[James Clerk Maxwell Telescope]] (JCMT): [[China]], [[Japan]], [[South Korea]], [[Taiwan]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]] * [[Subaru Telescope]]: [[National Astronomical Observatory of Japan]] * [[Submillimeter Array|Sub-Millimeter Array]] (SMA): [[Taiwan]], [[United States]] * [[United Kingdom Infrared Telescope]] (UKIRT): [[Lockheed Martin]] Advanced Technology Center, [[University of Hawaii|University of Hawaiʻi]], [[University of Arizona]] * [[UH88|University of Hawaiʻi {{convert|88|in|m|adj=on}} telescope]] (UH88): University of Hawaiʻi * [[UH24|University of Hawaiʻi {{convert|36|in|mm|adj=on}} telescope]] (Hoku Kea): [[University of Hawaii at Hilo]] * One receiver of the [[Very Long Baseline Array]] (VLBA): [[United States]] * [[W. M. Keck Observatory]]: California Association for Research in Astronomy
CSO, UKIRT, and UH88 are scheduled for decommissioning as part of the Mauna Kea Comprehensive Management Plan.<ref>{{cite web|title=Third Maunakea observatory set for decommissioning|url=http://www.hawaii.edu/news/2015/10/21/third-maunakea-observatory-set-for-decommissioning/|website=University of Hawaii News|publisher=University of Hawaii|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref>
==Opposition and protests== {{main|Opposition to the Mauna Kea Observatories}} In Honolulu, the governor and legislature, enthusiastic about the development, set aside an even larger area for the observatory after the initial project, causing opposition on the Big Island, in the city of [[Hilo, Hawaii|Hilo]]. [[Native Hawaiians]] (kānaka ʻōiwi) believed the entire site was sacred and that developing the mountain, even for science, would spoil the area. Environmentalists were concerned about rare native bird populations and other citizens of Hilo were concerned about the sight of the domes from the city. Using town hall meetings, Jefferies was able to overcome opposition by weighing the economic advantage and prestige the island would receive.<ref name="Zirker2005" /> There has been substantial opposition to the Mauna Kea observatories that continues to grow.<ref name="Oswalt2003">{{cite book|author=Terry D. Oswalt|title=The Future of Small Telescopes in the New Millennium|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9ZqLBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA18|date=2003|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-94-010-0253-0|page=18}}</ref> Over the years, the opposition to the observatories may have become the most visible example of the conflict science has encountered over access and use of environmental and culturally significant sites.<ref name="DearKetchum2011">{{cite book|author1=Michael Dear|author2=Jim Ketchum|author3=Sarah Luria|author4=Doug Richardson|title=GeoHumanities: Art, History, Text at the Edge of Place|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zwrJBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT476|date=13 April 2011|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-88347-7|page=476}}</ref> Opposition to development grew shortly after expansion of the observatories commenced. Once access was opened up by the roadway to the summit, skiers began using it for recreation and objected when the road was closed as a precaution against vandalism when the telescopes were being built. Hunters voiced concerns, as did the [[National Audubon Society|Hawaiian Audubon Society]] who were supported by Governor [[George Ariyoshi]].<ref name="PARKER2013" />{{rp|56}}
The Audubon Society objected to further development on Mauna Kea over concerns to habitat of the endangered [[Palila]], a species [[Endemism|endemic]] to only specific parts of this mountain. The bird is the last of the finch billed honeycreepers existing on the island. Over 50% of native bird species had been killed off due to loss of habitat from early western settlers or the introduction of non-native species competing for resources. Hunters and sportsmen were concerned that the hunting of feral animals would be affected by the telescope operations.<ref name="Gordon2007">{{cite book|author=Mark Gordon|title=Recollections of "Tucson Operations": The Millimeter-Wave Observatory of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iWPbIrwEKpMC&pg=PA136|date=18 July 2007|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4020-3236-3|pages=136–140}}</ref> A "Save Mauna Kea" movement was inspired by the proliferation of telescopes, with opposition believing development of the mountain to be sacrilegious.<ref name="Oaks2003">{{cite book|author=Robert F. Oaks|title=Hawaii:: A History of the Big Island|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HDVNJ5wzcisC&pg=PA131|date=1 November 2003|publisher=Arcadia Publishing | isbn=978-1-4396-1403-7|page=131}}</ref> Native Hawaiian non-profit groups, such as [[Kahea]], whose goals are the protection of cultural heritage and the environment, oppose development on Mauna Kea as a sacred space to the Hawaiian religion.<ref name="Kaufman2009">{{cite book|author=Ned Kaufman|title=Place, Race, and Story: Essays on the Past and Future of Historic Preservation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5fCTAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA14|date=11 September 2009|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-88972-2|page=14}}</ref> Today, Mauna Kea hosts the world's largest location for telescope observations in infrared and submillimeter astronomy. The land is protected by the United States Historical Preservation Act due to its significance to Hawaiian culture, but still allowed development.<ref name="Schachter2013">{{cite book|author=Judith Schachter|title=The Legacies of a Hawaiian Generation: From Territorial Subject to American Citizen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OTTUAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA43|date=15 September 2013|publisher=Berghahn Books|isbn=978-1-78238-012-2|page=43}}</ref>
==2006 Kiholo Bay earthquake== A number of the telescopes sustained minor damage during the October 15, [[2006 Kiholo Bay earthquake]] and aftershocks. JCMT was performing an inclinometry run and recorded the earthquake on its tilt sensors.<ref>{{cite web |first=Gary|last=Davis|title= News from the JCMT |date= 2007 |url=http://www.casca.ca/ecass/issues/2007-ve/news/jcmt/index.html|publisher=[[Canadian Astronomical Society]] |accessdate= 14 July 2015}}</ref> Both CFHT and W. M. Keck Observatory were operational and back online by October 19.<ref>{{cite web |title= 2006 October 15 Earthquake Aftermath at CFHT | publisher=[[Canada–France–Hawaii Telescope|Canada–France–Hawaiʻi Telescope]] |url= http://www.cfht.hawaii.edu/EARTHQUAKE/ |date= January 11, 2007 |accessdate= August 27, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Earthquake Update from W. M. Keck Observatory |publisher= W. M. Keck Observatory |url= http://keckobservatory.org/news/earthquake_update_from_w._m._keck_observatory/ |accessdate= August 27, 2010 }}</ref>
==See also== [[File:MaunaKeaSunset.jpg|right|thumb|Sunset over Mauna Kea Observatories]] * Lists and comparisons ** [[Timeline of telescopes, observatories, and observing technology]] ** [[List of largest optical reflecting telescopes]] ** [[List of largest optical telescopes historically]] ** [[Extremely large telescope]] * Other major international observatories (under active development): ** [[Roque de los Muchachos Observatory]] ** [[Paranal Observatory]] ** [[Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory]] ** [[Llano de Chajnantor Observatory]] ** [[La Silla Observatory]] * Historically important observatories (not undergoing substantial development): ** [[Mount Wilson Observatory]] ** [[Kitt Peak National Observatory]] ** [[Palomar Observatory]] * Projects ** [[Ohana project]]

{{infobox Organization |name = Max Planck Institute for
Comparative Public Law and International Law |image = |image_border = |size = 195px |abbreviation = MPIL |purpose = Basic research |formation = 1924 |headquarters = |location = [[Heidelberg]], Germany |leader_title = Co-Directors |leader_name = [[Armin von Bogdandy]] and [[Anne Peters]] |parent_organization = [[Max Planck Society]] |num_staff = approx. 100 |website = [http://www.mpil.de/ww/en/pub/news.cfm www.mpil.de] |remarks = }} The '''Max Planck Institute for Comparative Public Law and International Law''' ('''Max Planck Institute for International Law''', '''MPIL''') is a legal research institute located in [[Heidelberg]], [[Germany]]. It is operated by the [[Max Planck Society]]. The institute was founded in 1924 and was originally named the ''[[Kaiser Wilhelm Institute]] for Foreign and International Public Law'' and located in [[Berlin]]. It later relocated to Heidelberg and received its current name in 1949. The institute currently employs 69 scientific staff and is led by two co-directors, [[Armin von Bogdandy]] (since 2002) and [[Anne Peters]] (since 2013).{{cite web|url=http://www.mpil.de/ww/en/pub/research/profile/history.cfm|title=Max Planck Institute for Comparative Public Law and International Law - History and Organization|accessdate=2010-01-10|work=Max Planck Institute for Comparative Public Law and International Law website|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805001929/http://www.mpil.de/ww/en/pub/research/profile/history.cfm|archivedate=2012-08-05|df=}} It is seated at [[Heidelberg University]]'s [[New Campus (University of Heidelberg)|New Campus]]. The institute is one of the most important research institutions in the [[German language in Europe|German-speaking world]] in the fields of [[international law]], [[European law]], [[comparative law|comparative]] [[public law]], and for the theoretical frameworks of [[transnational law]]. It has traditionally performed important advisory functions for parliaments, administrative organs and courts concerned with questions of public international law, comparative public law and European law. In particular, the institute has provided the [[German Federal Constitutional Court]], the [[German Bundestag]] and the [[German Federal Government]] with information, expert testimony and counsel, representing the [[Germany|Federal Republic of Germany]] in several high-profile cases. The institute's directors regularly hold the chairs for international law at the [[University of Heidelberg Law School]]. Moreover, the institute's directors traditionally have held outstanding positions in national and international courts and bodies: * [[Hermann Mosler]], [[Justice (official)|Justice]] in the [[European Court of Human Rights]] (1959–1976); Justice in the [[International Court of Justice]] (1976–1985) * [[Rudolf Bernhardt]], President of the [[European Court of Human Rights]] (Justice 1981-1998, President 1992-1998) * [[Helmut Steinberger]], Justice in the [[German Federal Constitutional Court]] (1975–1987), Vice President of the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE Court of Conciliation and Arbitration]] (2001–2008) * [[Jochen Frowein]], Vice President of the [[European Commission for Human Rights]] (1977–1993) * [[Rüdiger Wolfrum]], President of the [[International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea]] (Justice since 1996, President 2005-2008) * [[Armin von Bogdandy]], President of the [[European Nuclear Energy Tribunal]] (Justice since 2001, President since 2006) * [http://www.mpil.de/en/pub/organization/management/directors/peters.cfm Anne Peters], Member (substitute) of the European Commission for Democracy through Law (Venice Commission) in respect of Germany (since 2011) Former research assistants include [[Hans-Peter Kaul]], sitting vice president of the [[International Criminal Court]],{{cite web |url=http://www.icc-cpi.int/NR/rdonlyres/C50AA5FD-A78B-4C91-950D-5EE3A9759A18/141522/ICCASP_ej2_gercv.pdf|title=Curriculum Vitae of Hans-Peter Kaul|accessdate=2008-05-17 |format=pdf|work=International Criminal Court website}} [[Juliane Kokott]], sitting [[Advocate General]] of the [[European Court of Justice]],[http://curia.europa.eu/jcms/jcms/Jo2_7026/ Biographies of the Members of the European Court of Justice] former Justice in the [[International Court of Justice]] [[Carl-August Fleischhauer]],''Carl-August Fleischhauer.'' In: Arthur Eyffinger, Arthur Witteveen, [[Mohammed Bedjaoui]]: ''La Cour internationale de Justice 1946–1996.'' Martinus Nijhoff Publishers, Den Haag und London 1999, {{ISBN|90-411-0468-2}}, S. 283 and [[Georg Nolte]], present member of the [[United Nations]] [[International Law Commission]].{{cite web |url=http://nolte.rewi.hu-berlin.de/cv/|title=Curriculum Vitae of Georg Nolte|accessdate=2008-05-17 |work=Humboldt University website}} With 630.000 volumes, the institute's library contains the largest collection for [[international law]], [[European law]], and [[public law]] in [[Europe]]. Regular publications by the institute include the "Heidelberg Journal for International Law", the "Max Planck Yearbook of United Nations Law"; the "Journal of the History of International Law"; the "Max Planck Encyclopedia of Public International Law"; and the semi-annual bibliography "Public International Law".{{cite web|url=http://www.mpil.de/ww/en/pub/research/profile/publ.cfm|title=Publications of the Institute|accessdate=2008-05-17|format=cfm|work=Max Planck Institute for Comparative Public Law and International Law website|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060831182223/http://www.mpil.de/ww/en/pub/research/profile/publ.cfm|archivedate=2006-08-31|df=}} Guests are involved in the institute’s programs, especially symposia, lectures and the weekly meetings of the research staff, as well as various staff-led working groups on specific subject areas. == Directors == [[File:Max-Planck-Institute for Comparative Public Law and International Law from Flickr 523874826.jpg|thumb|300px|The building of the institute in [[Heidelberg]].]] * [[Carl Bilfinger]] (1950–1954) * [[Hermann Mosler]] (1954–1980) * [[Rudolf Bernhardt]] (1970–1993) * [[Karl Doehring]] (1963-1987) * [[Helmut Steinberger]] (1987-1997) * [[Jochen Frowein]] (1981–2002) * [[Rüdiger Wolfrum]] (1993-2012) * [[Armin von Bogdandy]] (since 2002) * [[Anne Peters]] (since 2013) == See also == * [[Max Planck Society]] * [[University of Heidelberg]] * [[Heidelberg University Faculty of Law]] * [[Max Planck Encyclopedia of Public International Law]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{coord missing|Germany}} {{Authority control}} {{Max Planck Society}} [[Category:Max Planck Institutes|Comparative Public Law and International Law]] [[Category:Legal research institutes]] [[Category:Heidelberg]]
